item.title: Hundreds of Hamas Fighters Are Stuck in Tunnels in Israeli-Controlled Gaza
item.description: The presence of the militants, who have killed three Israeli troops, is threatening to unravel the fragile cease-fire.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Trump Expresses Reservations Over Strikes in Venezuela to Top Aides
item.description: The Trump administration is still deciding whether to oust Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro or extract concessions from him, according to U.S. officials familiar with the deliberations.
item.dc:creator: Lara Seligman

item.title: Bank of Canada Gov. Macklem Tells Lawmakers Rate Policy at ‘Right’ Level
item.description: Economic growth is expected to remain tepid through the second half of 2025, he said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: Opinion | Trump’s Strange Love Affair With Pakistan
item.description: Army chief Asim Munir has managed to get on the U.S. president’s good side with diplomacy and promises likely to prove empty.
item.dc:creator: Sadanand Dhume

item.title: Opinion | Hitting Putin Where It Hurts
item.description: Ukraine is increasingly striking at energy and arms targets in Russia.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | The Lessons of Ukraine’s Drone Warfare
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have a lot to learn—and stand to pay an enormous price if they fail to do so.
item.dc:creator: Jillian Kay Melchior

item.title: Opinion | Trump Has the Legal Power to Bomb Drug Boats
item.description: But Congress can stop it by constitutional means—namely by employing the power of the purse.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas B. Creel

item.title: Putin Paves Way to Resume Nuclear Testing as Tensions Flare With Trump
item.description: The Russian leader said Moscow could return to nuclear testing if the U.S. begins testing its own arsenal.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Brazil Is Developing a Weapon for Trade Wars: Fertilizer in the Amazon
item.description: A planned $2.5 billion potash mine in the rainforest is billed as key to Brazil’s expanding agricultural exports and to the economic security of the indigenous population.
item.dc:creator: Samantha Pearson

item.title: France to Suspend Shein Sales After Finding Childlike Sex Dolls, Weapons
item.description: The order came as the Chinese-founded platform opened its first permanent store, which is in Paris.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: Opinion | A Taiwan Test for Trump? His Hands Are Tied
item.description: The island’s status is a fixed matter of U.S. law, not amenable to the president’s discretion.

item.title: Opinion | Madrid Didn’t Get the Memo
item.description: If we need to withdraw troop, perhaps it should be from Spain, the only NATO member to reject raising defense expenditures to 5% of GDP..

item.title: EU Countries Agree Weaker Climate Targets Ahead of COP30
item.description: Deal lets European Union countries make up 5% of their national emissions reductions targets through carbon credits
item.dc:creator: Edith Hancock

item.title: German Factory Orders, French Industrial Output Rebound After Recent Slumps
item.description: The results signal a recovery in the factory sector after trade uncertainty dented demand over the summer.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Hamas Returns Last Dead American-Israeli Hostage to Israel
item.description: A total of seven dead hostages remain in Gaza after the return of the body of Israeli-American soldier Itay Chen.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: How China’s Chokehold on Drugs, Chips and More Threatens the U.S.
item.description: It isn’t just rare earths. Three products show how Beijing built supply-chain dominance that it can use to hurt its trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: Russia’s New War Grifters—‘Black Widows’ Duping Soldiers Into Marriage
item.description: Authorities say women are marrying servicemen in an attempt to get the death payouts that go to their families.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: Canada Plans Wider Deficits to Jolt Economy
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney’s government said it would cut the size of the federal public-sector workforce by about 5%, or 16,000 jobs.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: White House Seeks Sanctions Repeal Ahead of Syrian President’s Talks With Trump
item.description: The Senate supports lifting restrictions on fledging Damascus government, but some House members have been wary.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: One Caribbean Leader Is Going All-Out for Trump Against Venezuela
item.description: Trinidad and Tobago’s prime minister is hosting U.S. warships and cheering strikes on alleged drug boats in a high-risk gamble on regime change in Caracas.
item.dc:creator: Kejal Vyas

item.title: Dick Cheney, Powerful Former Vice President Who Served Four Republican Presidents, Dies at 84
item.description: The national-security hawk was an architect of the post-9/11 U.S. war on terror.
item.dc:creator: John D. McKinnon

item.title: U.K. Treasury Chief Says Lowering Inflation Will Be Budget Focus
item.description: Reeves declined to rule out a rise in taxes, which many see as the only option left to the government if it is to achieve its goals.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Japan Is Overrun With Tourists. This City Wants More.
item.description: Nagoya is Japan’s fourth-largest city, but a lot of people think it’s No. 1 in dullness.
item.dc:creator: Junko Fukutome

item.title: Why a Song for Sad English Soccer Fans Is at the Center of a Fight Gripping Africa
item.description: Supporters of a deceased Zambian president have appropriated “Three Lions” in their campaign to bring his body home.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: A Mayor’s Assassination Reignites Mexico’s Debate Over Confronting Cartels
item.description: President Claudia Sheinbaum says Mexico won’t return to the violent war on drug traffickers some opponents say is necessary.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Trump Officials Torpedoed Nvidia’s Push to Export AI Chips to China
item.description: The president decided against discussing the matter with Chinese leader Xi Jinping after top aides opposed it.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Whelan

item.title: Israel Detains Former Top Military Lawyer Over Leaked Video of Alleged Prisoner Abuse
item.description: Police said they detained Maj. Gen. Yifat Tomer-Yerushalmi after she acknowledged leaking a video at the center of a case of alleged abuse against Palestinian prisoners.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: The Billionaire Trader Who Swooped In on Russia’s Overseas Oil Empire
item.description: Torbjörn Törnqvist has just struck one of the deals of his lifetime, pouncing on Lukoil’s overseas operations soon after it was hit with U.S. sanctions.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: Rheinmetall Joint Venture Invests $577 Million to Produce Propellant Powder in Romania
item.description: The German arms maker and the Romanian defense company signed a deal Monday to form a joint venture, with Rheinmetall holding 51% and Pirochim owning the remainder.
item.dc:creator: Cristina Gallardo

item.title: Trump Says Xi Will Help Fight Fentanyl. Will China Follow Through?
item.description: The challenge for the U.S. is to make sure that Beijing takes action—and sustains its cooperation, particularly when it has consistently pushed back against U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Tariff-Driven Shifts Continue to Shape Asia’s Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Factory activity gauges in Asia reflected a divergence across major exporting economies.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Kao

item.title: Vietnam Is Building Islands to Challenge China’s Hold on a Vital Waterway
item.description: The contested South China Sea boasts rich oil and gas reserves and could play a key role in a conflict over Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Ming Li

item.title: China Manufacturing Gauge Signals Weaker Growth Momentum
item.description: A private gauge of China’s manufacturing activity showed Chinese factories continued to increase production in October, albeit at a slower pace.

item.title: Europe’s Role Reversal: The Problem Economies Are Now Farther North
item.description: France, the U.K. and Germany have growing budget deficits and debt, while the former crisis hot spots in the south look financially healthier.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: The Arab World’s Last Militant Leader Is Elusive and Defiant
item.description: Israel has battered its enemy commanders into submission except one: Abdulmalik Al-Houthi, a secrecy-obsessed fighter whose followers believe he is anointed by God.
item.dc:creator: Summer Said

item.title: Assassin Guns Down Mexican Mayor Who Pleaded for Hard Line Against Cartels
item.description: Mayor Carlos Manzo of Uruapan in Western Mexico took on cartels that ran extortion rackets on avocado growers.
item.dc:creator: José de Córdoba

item.title: Trump Threatens Military Action in Nigeria in Defense of Christians
item.description: The president said the U.S. could go in “guns-a-blazing” to halt the perceived targeting of Christians by Islamist militants.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Wexler

item.title: Mass Stabbing on Train to London Causes Life-Threatening Injuries
item.description: Police made two arrests after the train was stopped in Huntingdon, near Cambridge, and say there is no sign of a terrorist motive.

item.title: Next Question for Gaza Peace Plan: Who Wants to Police It?
item.description: Any country sending troops to keep the peace in the enclave could risk having a run-in with Hamas, which says it will resist any attempt to confront it.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: China Is Filling Up Its Oil Reserves Fast
item.description: The cushion could protect the country from any short-term supply disruptions related to new U.S. sanctions on Russian crude.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Feng

item.title: Xi-Trump Deal Leads to Resumed Shipments of Crucial Auto Semiconductors
item.description: Nexperia hasn’t shipped chips for weeks, putting car production around the world at risk.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Felton

item.title: Canadian PM Carney Says He Apologized to Trump Over Antitariff Ad
item.description: Canada’s prime minister said he made the apology to President Trump during a dinner earlier this week at the international economic summit in South Korea, where he also met with China’s Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Yoko Kubota

item.title: The Trade War Couldn’t Change China’s Economy
item.description: American hopes for political reform in China faded years ago, and now hopes for economic liberalization are fading too.
item.dc:creator: Jason Douglas

item.title: Trump Says He’s Not Planning Venezuela Strike
item.description: The president had said recently the U.S. was considering strikes against targets in the country.
item.dc:creator: Anvee Bhutani

item.title: Israel’s Top Military Lawyer Steps Down Amid Leak Controversy
item.description: The official resigned after an investigation was launched into her alleged role in authorizing the release of footage that appeared to show soldiers assaulting a Palestinian detainee.
item.dc:creator: Feliz Solomon

item.title: Argentina Has the World’s Weirdest Tax. Can Milei Scrap it?
item.description: Argentina’s export tax hurts its critical agricultural industry. President Javier Milei has yet to follow through on a promise to end it.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ip

item.title: Key Moments in the Downfall of Prince Andrew
item.description: The British royal’s unprecedented disgrace follows years of scandal and sexual-abuse allegations.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Dangoor

item.title: Why Buckingham Palace Decided to Get Rid of Andrew
item.description: In demoting the errant prince, King Charles hopes to get the monarchy scandal-free for his son William.
item.dc:creator: David Luhnow

item.title: Inside the Low-Tech Heist That Penetrated the Louvre
item.description: The men who stole France’s crown jewels cut corners—mistakes that led authorities to track down three suspected thieves.
item.dc:creator: Noemie Bisserbe

item.title: BOE to Embrace Uncertainty, and Bernanke’s Guidance, With Communications Revamp
item.description: The central bank place will more emphasis on developments that could upend its expectations and less on forecasts that convey too much certainty about the future.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Sudan Militia, Armed With Drones, Hunts Down Black Population of Darfur
item.description: The country’s civil war has triggered a wave of brutal reprisals targeting the region’s Black population.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: China Factory Activity Gauge Signals Deepening Manufacturing Gloom
item.description: Economic momentum continued to weaken for the world’s second-largest economy, with a manufacturing gauge signaling mounting headwinds.

item.title: U.S. Eyes Striking Venezuelan Military Targets Used for Drug Trafficking
item.description: If President Trump decides to move forward with airstrikes, the targets would send a clear message to Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro that it is time to step down, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Vera Bergengruen

item.title: Al Qaeda Is on the Brink of Taking Over a Country
item.description: If the jihadists succeed in taking Mali, it would become the first country run by the group. The U.S. has warned its citizens to leave the West African nation immediately.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Washington’s Oil Dilemma Returns: How to Hurt Moscow Without Raising Gas Prices
item.description: Enforcing tough measures against one of the world’s top oil producers risks triggering a supply shock.
item.dc:creator: Laurence Norman

item.title: How U.A.E. Arms Bolstered a Sudanese Militia Accused of Genocide
item.description: Reports by U.S. intelligence agencies show an increase in the flow of materiel from the U.A.E. to the rebel Rapid Support Forces since the spring, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Putin Uses Old Missile Technology to Send a New Message to the West
item.description: President Vladimir Putin hailed the first long-distance test of a nuclear-powered cruise missile that he said has no equal in the West.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: How Russia’s Sanctioned Arctic Gas Found a Chinese Loophole
item.description: The U.S. and its allies have tried to cripple Russia’s energy industry, but Moscow has found loopholes time and again.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Feng

item.title: State Department Intelligence Agency Dissented Over Putin’s Appetite for Peace
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency had a more positive assessment of the Russian leader’s willingness to talk.
item.dc:creator: Brett Forrest

item.title: Will India and China Be Able to Resist U.S. Sanctions on Russian Oil?
item.description: New Delhi and Beijing have so far resisted U.S. calls to stop buying Russian crude, but far-reaching sanctions will be hard to ignore.
item.dc:creator: Jiahui Huang

item.title: Trump Signals Support for Selling Submarines to Australia
item.description: The president’s comments calmed fears that he would pull out of the Biden-era deal and came as he struck an agreement with the U.S. ally on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: How a Right-Wing Hindu Group Went From Fringe to Mainstream in India
item.description: India’s Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh group is stepping out of the shadows and flexing its power.

item.title: Trump Organization Expands in India, Where Many of Its Partners Face Accusations
item.description: Indian real-estate firms have been accused of fraud, money laundering and more on other projects. The Trumps have stepped up overseas deals in the president’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Peter Grant

item.title: India Delicately Counters Trump Claim It Will Drop Russian Oil
item.description: New Delhi didn’t outright contradict the president, saying it was committed to protecting consumers by diversifying its energy supplies.
item.dc:creator: Shan Li

item.title: The Path to the American Dream Is Narrowing for Indian Tech Workers
item.description: About 70% of H-1B visas go to Indians. Looming changes to the program are upending plans, but may help India retain talent.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Pentagon Review of Aukus Security Pact Worries U.K., Australia
item.description: The review throws into doubt a strategic partnership that aims to give Australia nuclear-powered submarines and deter Chinese aggression in the Indo-Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Russia’s Side Quest to Dominate Africa: Hijack a Videogame
item.description: Players in the ‘African Dawn’ videogame are asked to choose a side aligned with either Russia or the West.
item.dc:creator: Sarah E. Needleman

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
